title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [25 february 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [25 February 1868]
text: tuesdayTuesdaywell Waltwe have lived to see something that never was i suppose known before in americaAmerica the impeachment) i think it rather sad but notwithstanding exactly as it should be i suppose the excitement at washingtonWashington is far greater than here the copperheads here is all for fight that a war will be 25 Feb 68 the result some great politician down town wanted to bet yesterday that the impeachment would not take place so our georgey took him up told him he would bet him that andrew JohnsoAndrew Johnson would be impeached in ten hours from that time the gentleman backed down after putting his hand in his pocket to take out his money george came home on sundaySunday morning very unexpected as i didentdidn't look for him till next saturdaySaturday he came something about the iron of the pipes he rejected as unfit) i got your letter walter yesterday mondayMonday with 5 dollars i was glad to have it walt but i doodo think sometimes you send me more than you can afford and more than i ought to expect but mamma appreciates it if she dontdon't make many walt you wrote about your peicepiece in an english magazine that you got 50 d in gold its first rate to handle gold in these days but i want to know what peicepiece it was i thought of every one and could not make out what peicepiece it was when you write again i wish you would tell me all about it but the gold is quite a new thing to be paid in these days) i think we will get the galaxy and see Oconors peicepiece if its as stupid as his others i dontdon't think it will be worth 25 ctscents i dontdon't see into his writing such peicespieces as he writes i should think him capable of writing something more substancialsubstantial a man that can converse as he canwell davis was here last sundaySunday he gave a good account of the st louisSt. Louis folks he says jeff is much better there than here it agrees with him better and he thinks matty will be all right when they get settled he says they all felt the effects of the change of climate its affect is a kind of diareadiarrhea he says he thinks matty will like it better there than here when they get to housekeeping it is in the neighborhood of general ShermansGeneral Sherman's house that was presented to him) and a nice sckoolschool near he davis looks very well indeed says he is very glad he went out there that he and Jeff has worked very hard but have got through the worst of it aintain't it been cold Walt i gessguess it has been stinging here but itsit's quite moderate to day) i have heard nothing from aunt fanny i suppossuppose she is living yet) the last speech of stephensStevens that was read before the impeachment was good very indeed)i am pretty well good bye walt dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [25 February 1868]
